results.headline: Saddle the Wind
results.summary_short: Ex-gunslinger's wild younger brother comes to town. Crisp, cutting, well-played.

results.headline: South Pacific
results.summary_short: Rodgers and Hammerstein's love-and-racism musical in banana-split color. Fine earful but don't expect Broadway magic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of South Pacific

results.headline: Teacher's Pet
results.summary_short: Tough city editor and journalism teacher. Literate, first-rate comedy.

results.headline: Desire Under the Elms
results.summary_short: O'Neill's farm triangle. Branches heavy with stagy, stilted treatment and Burl's foxy papa. But fine Sophia and Tony.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desire Under the Elms

results.headline: Unholy Wife, The
results.summary_short: The old triangle, Gothic ranch. Clanky stuff. Steiger's awful.

results.headline: I Accuse!
results.summary_short: The Dreyfus case. Well done but not especially forceful. Viveca best.

results.headline: Mark of the Hawk, The
results.summary_short: African racism. Earnest and thoughtful, conventional and rambling.

results.headline: Monte Carlo Story, The
results.summary_short: Pretty and mild, but worthwhile to hear Marlene warble ""Back Home In Indiana.'' Attagirl.

results.headline: Witness for the Prosecution
results.summary_short: Classy, juicy version of Christie's stage puzzler, via Billy Wilder. Keep your eye on Marlene.

results.headline: Quiet American, The
results.summary_short: Graham Greene's naive American blunderer in Saigon. Politically bland but good ambience and intriguing as a whodunit.
